The numerator of the rational number is an integer.

name: Rat.num
docString: The numerator of the rational number is an integer.

For any rational number 'n', the conversion of 'n' to a rational number yields the same value.

name: Rat.cast_id
docString: For any rational number 'n', the conversion of 'n' to a rational number yields the same value.

This theorem asserts that for any rational number 'n', casting 'n' to a rational number results in 'n' itself. In other words, if a variable is already a rational number, casting it as a rational number doesn't change its value.

name: Rat.cast_id
docString: This theorem asserts that for any rational number 'n', casting 'n' to a rational number results in 'n' itself. In other words, if a variable is already a rational number, casting it as a rational number doesn't change its value.

**Denumerability of the Rational Numbers**

name: Rat.instDenumerable
docString: **Denumerability of the Rational Numbers**

The denominator of every rational number is positive.

name: Rat.den_pos
docString: The denominator of every rational number is positive.

This theorem states that for any real number `x`, natural number `n`, integer `m`, and natural number `p` where `p` is a prime number, if `x` to the power `n` equals `m` (which is not zero), and `n` does not divide the highest power of `p` that still divides `m` (in other words, the remainder when the multiplicity of `p` in `m` is divided by `n` is not zero), then `x` is an irrational number. This means that `x` cannot be expressed as a fraction of two integers.

type:
∀ {x : ℝ} (n : ℕ) {m : ℤ} (hm : m ≠ 0) (p : ℕ) [hp : Fact p.Prime],
  x ^ n = ↑m → (multiplicity (↑p) m).get ⋯ % n ≠ 0 → Irrational x
name: irrational_nrt_of_n_not_dvd_multiplicity
docString: This theorem states that for any real number `x`, natural number `n`, integer `m`, and natural number `p` where `p` is a prime number, if `x` to the power `n` equals `m` (which is not zero), and `n` does not divide the highest power of `p` that still divides `m` (in other words, the remainder when the multiplicity of `p` in `m` is divided by `n` is not zero), then `x` is an irrational number. This means that `x` cannot be expressed as a fraction of two integers.

The denominator of the rational number is a natural number.

name: Rat.den
docString: The denominator of the rational number is a natural number.

If a rational is not a p-adic integer, it is not an integer.

type: ∀ (p : ℕ) {a : ℚ} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], 1 < padicNorm p a → ¬a.isInt = true
name: padicNorm.not_int_of_not_padic_int
docString: If a rational is not a p-adic integer, it is not an integer.

If `x^n`, `n > 0`, is integer and is not the `n`-th power of an integer, then
`x` is irrational.

type: ∀ {x : ℝ} (n : ℕ) (m : ℤ), x ^ n = ↑m → (¬∃ y, x = ↑y) → 0 < n → Irrational x
name: irrational_nrt_of_notint_nrt
docString:
If `x^n`, `n > 0`, is integer and is not the `n`-th power of an integer, then
`x` is irrational.

Every finite convergent corresponds to a rational number.

type:
∀ {K : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedField K] [inst_1 : FloorRing K] (v : K) (n : ℕ),
  ∃ q, (GenContFract.of v).convs n = ↑q
name: GenContFract.exists_rat_eq_nth_conv
docString: Every finite convergent corresponds to a rational number.

Every terminating continued fraction corresponds to a rational number.

  (GenContFract.of v).Terminates → ∃ q, v = ↑q
name: GenContFract.exists_rat_eq_of_terminates
docString: Every terminating continued fraction corresponds to a rational number.

A real number is irrational if it is not equal to any rational number.

name: Irrational
docString: A real number is irrational if it is not equal to any rational number.

If `x^n = m` is an integer and `n` does not divide the `multiplicity p m`, then `x`
is irrational.

type:
∀ {x : ℝ} (n : ℕ) {m : ℤ},
  m ≠ 0 → ∀ (p : ℕ) [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], x ^ n = ↑m → multiplicity (↑p) m % n ≠ 0 → Irrational x
name: irrational_nrt_of_n_not_dvd_multiplicity
docString:
If `x^n = m` is an integer and `n` does not divide the `multiplicity p m`, then `x`
is irrational.

Rational numbers are dense in a linear ordered archimedean field.

type:
∀ {�� : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedField ��] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace ��] [inst_2 : OrderTopology ��]
  [inst_3 : Archimedean ��], DenseRange Rat.cast

docString: Rational numbers are dense in a linear ordered archimedean field.

If `ξ` is rational, then the good rational approximations to `ξ` have bounded
numerator and denominator.

type: ∀ {ξ q : ℚ}, |ξ - q| < 1 / ↑q.den ^ 2 → q.den ≤ ξ.den ∧ ⌈ξ * ↑q.den⌉ - 1 ≤ q.num ∧ q.num ≤ ⌊ξ * ↑q.den⌋ + 1
name: Rat.den_le_and_le_num_le_of_sub_lt_one_div_den_sq
docString:
If `ξ` is rational, then the good rational approximations to `ξ` have bounded
numerator and denominator.

The product of a Liouville number and a nonzero rational number is again a Liouville number.

type: ∀ {p x : ℝ} {r : ℚ}, LiouvilleWith p x → r ≠ 0 → LiouvilleWith p (x * ↑r)
name: LiouvilleWith.mul_rat
docString: The product of a Liouville number and a nonzero rational number is again a Liouville number.

The set of good rational approximations to a real number `ξ` is infinite if and only if
`ξ` is irrational.

name: Real.infinite_rat_abs_sub_lt_one_div_den_sq_iff_irrational
docString:
The set of good rational approximations to a real number `ξ` is infinite if and only if
`ξ` is irrational.
